author: closer__
content:
1. why are fork id non `0x` prefixed and chain id is?
2. why is precompile map address to string and system contract map string to address

author: closer__
content: i see nethermind's config has system contracts as address to string, would prefer the consistent variant

author: closer__
content:
~~one more question: why does `eth_config` only show current and next fork, why don't we render _all_ forks with their fork ids, timestamps (or whatever the activtion condition was) and related configurations?~~
edit: i guess that's explained by this part of the EIP
```
This EIP does not alter previous behavior. Configurations prior to Cancun are non-standard, and clients sharing pre-Cancun configurations will produce non-standard results.
```

author: closer__
content: actually, <@277500722655002624> i think that chain id is in the fork config so that it would be part of the fork hash

author: __flcl
content: ~~Do you mean chain id should stay in current/next?~~

author: __flcl
content: Btw should we mention secp256r1? How to name it? SEC_P256_R1? NIST_P256?

author: __flcl
content: As for whether systemContracts should have address as the key or not - no preference, it was a bug

author: marioevz
content: I think the precompiles and system contracts should have the same format IMO, and also the fork ID and config hash should both have the 0x prefix, I could add those two suggestions to the PR if everyone is ok with it <@519796549279023105>

author: raulvk
content: opened a PR after discussing with <@360491619402776577>: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/674

author: marioevz
content: `P256VERIFY` if we take the naming used in the EIP here: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7951#precompile

author: marioevz
content:
Updated the PR to:
- Include specification for BPOs
- Add 0x to the hex representation of fork id and fork hash
- Modify system contract representation to use the same format as precompiles

author: siladu
content:
I suspect the arrangement of `name: address` was because it makes more sense to sort the name alphabetically, whereas precompile addresses have a natural order and make more sense sorted by address. 
Since this is designed to be human readable I prefer the `name: address` approach for system contracts even if it's not nicely "symmetrical" from a code perspective.
